predictions.reasoning: First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with 11 files changed (M-sized scope). CLAWDINATOR bot comment signals triage rejection citing provider integration policy. Author response references discussion in #2838 but does not address the bot's closure statement. No human reviewer approval, no maintainer label, no maintainer comment engagement. Combines first-time status, moderate scope, and explicit triage bot closure signal indicating project policy gate. P-8-2 pattern applies: zero reviews/comments from first-time contributor despite CI passing.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS scope (3 files). No comments beyond Greptile automated review. No human reviewer engagement, no maintainer label, no maintainer comment. Applies P-8-2 pattern: zero comments/reviews from first-time contributor even with narrow scope and passing CI. Small size (3 files) provides modest positive signal but insufficient to override first-time status + zero engagement combination.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with XS scope (3 files, security-focused). Only Greptile automated review present. No human reviewer comments or approvals. No maintainer engagement or label. Applies P-8-2 pattern: zero human reviews/comments from first-time contributor. Security fix quality is positive signal but insufficient to overcome first-time status + zero engagement combination.

Author has strong merge history (1 prior PR, 100% merge rate). XS scope (1 file, docs-only). Greptile flagged documentation inconsistency but this is a minor fix opportunity, not a blocker. No maintainer label required for established contributor with perfect merge rate on narrow scope. Author engagement is implicit in submission. Size (1 file) and category (docs) are historically high-merge patterns.

Author has moderate history (7 prior PRs, 14.3% merge rate, 1 merged). Multiple self-advocacy comments showing iterative work and maintenance (rebasing, CI retrigger). Applies P-9-2 pattern: author maintenance comments (rebases, sync, CI retrigger) without maintainer engagement signal stalled PR. M-sized scope (7 files) adds complexity. No maintainer label, no maintainer comment, only Greptile review. Low merge rate for prior work suggests pattern of PRs not landing. Author responsiveness is positive but insufficient without maintainer signal.

Explicit supersession signal: author comment 'Superseded by new PR with clean rebase onto latest upstream/main' with replacement PR link #15825. Applies P-14-2 terminal pattern: PR explicitly stated as superseded by another PR. Author has weak history (1 prior PR, 0% merge rate). L-sized scope (24 files) with multi-channel touches adds risk. Supersession comment is definitive closure indicator regardless of technical quality, author history, or review presence.

Author comment explicitly states: 'Closing — issue #12247 was closed as completed. The maintainer's root cause analysis confirmed this was not an inbound newline-loss bug in normalizeMention(). The actual fix was submitted in #12809.' Applies P-11-2 pattern: maintainer analysis (via author citation) indicates fix landed elsewhere (#12809). PR superseded by another solution. Author has moderate history (29 prior PRs, 41.4% merge rate) but supersession is terminal signal.

Author comment: 'Closing — this PR is stale and has conflicts with the current main branch. Will re-submit if the issue is still relevant.' Author self-closure with explicit staleness and conflicts. Despite author's strong history (75 prior PRs, experienced-contributor label), author themselves determined PR no longer viable. XS scope (1 file) and agent category are normally positive, but author's explicit closure determination is definitive. Applies P-8-2 contextually: even experienced contributors acknowledge when PRs become stale.

Member comment explicitly states closure: 'Closing for now — we don't currently publish a config JSON Schema at https://openclaw.ai/config.json, so accepting $schema would mislead users/editor tooling into expecting a valid schema URL. Let's revisit once we have a stable, published schema endpoint...' Member decision to close with clear conditional (need published schema endpoint first). XS scope (2 files) positive but member's architectural decision overrides. Applies P-16-2: maintainer design-intent statement (unpublished schema policy) is terminal non-merge signal.

Member comment: 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue.' Author has been blocked by project maintainers for spam/quality issues. XS scope (3 files) and prior PR history (83 PRs, 4.8% merge rate, low merge rate author) are irrelevant given explicit member account action. Terminal closure signal: author enforcement action.

Author has 0% merge rate (0/4 prior PRs). First-time contributor to this codebase. Despite automated Greptile review comments and a member comment, there is no human reviewer approval or maintainer label. The PR touches slack channel logic but lacks the strong signals needed for first-time contributors: no maintainer label, no human approval, no maintainer engagement beyond a brief member comment. PATTERN: First-time contributors with no human reviewer engagement and no maintainer label do not reliably merge even with focused scope and tests.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with a medium-sized documentation PR (16 files). Despite having automated Greptile review, there are zero human reviewer comments, zero human approvals, and no maintainer label or engagement. PATTERN: PRs with zero reviews and no comments from first-time contributors, even with focused scope, have low merge probability. Additionally, PATTERN: First-time contributors with a maintainer label but zero human reviewer comments/approvals do not reliably merge—this PR lacks even the label. No evidence of merge readiness signals.

Author has 0% merge rate (0/6 prior PRs) combined with a massive XL-sized PR (101 files). This is a compounded non-merge signal. Although the author provides explanations for CI failures, there is zero human reviewer engagement or approval. PATTERN: XL-sized PRs (15+ files) from authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs and no human reviewer engagement are very unlikely to merge. The PR is not from a first-time contributor but persistent low merge history is equally disqualifying without maintainer approval.

TERMINAL SIGNAL: Author's own comment states 'Closing as obsolete. Upstream commit c76288bdf (PR #15447) already fixes issue #7536 along with #11892.' This is an explicit supersession statement. PATTERN: A contributor comment stating a PR is 'superseded by #NNNN' or equivalent phrasing indicates the work was absorbed by another PR and the original will not be merged, regardless of technical quality or author history. The author explicitly closed this PR citing a replacement PR #15447 with equivalent/superior functionality. Override any positive signals (author has 20% merge rate, experienced-contributor label, multiple reviews).

Author closes the PR directly with comment: 'Closing — 1357-line translation PR is too large for review.' This is an explicit author-initiated closure. Although the author is 0xRaini (top contributor with 134 prior PRs historically), this account shows 0 prior PRs and 0% merge rate in the current analysis, suggesting a data anomaly or account issue. The PR has automated reviews but no human reviewer approval. The author's own statement that the PR is 'too large for review' indicates they are withdrawing it. Terminal closure signal from author.

TERMINAL SIGNAL: Author's own comment states 'Superseded by new PR with clean rebase onto latest upstream/main. See replacement PR.' and 'Replacement PR: https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/15824'. This is an explicit supersession statement. PATTERN: A contributor comment stating a PR is 'superseded by #NNNN' or equivalent phrasing indicates the work was absorbed by another PR. Despite the PR having automated review engagement and author responses, the author has explicitly closed this PR in favor of a replacement. Author has 0% merge rate (0/7 prior PRs), compounding the non-merge signal. XL-sized PR (24 files) with persistent low merge history and explicit supersession = terminal closure.

Multiple terminal closure signals: (1) PR is in DRAFT status. (2) First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate). (3) Author's own comment reveals the PR was pushed to wrong repo: 'My bot pushed to wrong repo.. supposed to my fork.. sorry guys.' This is an explicit statement that the PR is misplaced and not intended for this repository. (4) Despite automated reviews, there is no human reviewer engagement or approval. PATTERN: Draft PRs combined with author admission of misdirected submission = terminal non-merge signal. Additionally, PATTERN: PRs with zero human reviews and zero comments from first-time contributors have low merge probability.

TERMINAL SIGNAL: Author's own comment states 'Closing: the linked issue #16694 has been resolved and closed on 2026-02-15. This PR is no longer needed.' This is a direct author-initiated closure indicating the underlying issue has been resolved elsewhere. While the author has a low but non-zero merge rate (6.8%, 3/44 prior PRs) and the PR is small (2 files, size: S), the author's explicit statement that the PR is 'no longer needed' because the issue is already closed indicates the fix landed elsewhere. PATTERN: A maintainer comment stating a PR is 'Fixed on main' or equivalent indicates the change landed elsewhere—this applies to author statements as well.

TERMINAL SIGNAL: Author's own comment states 'Closing — overlaps with #17205 which covers the same scopes issue more completely.' This is an explicit supersession/overlap statement indicating the work is better addressed in PR #17205. PATTERN: A contributor comment stating a PR is 'superseded by' or 'overlaps with' another PR indicates the work was absorbed elsewhere. Although the author has a low but non-zero merge rate (5.6%, 1/18 prior PRs) and the PR touches multiple areas (16 files, multiple labels), the author's statement that the issue is covered more completely elsewhere is a terminal closure signal. XL-sized scope with persistent low merge history compounds the non-merge signal.

Author (zerone0x) has a strong prior merge rate (66.7%, 6/9 prior PRs), well above baseline. PR has experienced-contributor label and is small in scope (3 files, size: S). Although the PR has zero comments and zero reviews, the author's strong track record and experienced-contributor label are positive signals. The PR touches discord channel logic with CHANGELOG inclusion, indicating deliberate change documentation. PATTERN: Experienced contributors with high prior merge rates and relevant labels have elevated merge probability even without explicit review engagement. Small focused scope with small file count (3 files) also supports merge prediction. No terminal negative signals present.

Author explicitly closed the PR with statement 'Closing as we've moved to our own ClawReach implementation and no longer need this upstream.' This is a terminal non-merge signal. Combined with 0% author merge rate (0/0 prior), stale label, and lack of maintainer engagement, this is not a merge candidate.

Author explicitly closed PR with 'Closing as we've moved to our own ClawReach implementation and no longer need this upstream.' Terminal non-merge signal overrides any technical quality. Author has 0% merge rate (0/1), stale label present. Same pattern as PR #5475—likely related PRs from same author abandoning upstream work.

Author has 0% merge rate across 10 prior PRs—a strong negative signal (P-3-1 pattern). No maintainer label, no maintainer comment, only 1 comment from author stating 'clean branch from upstream/main' (maintenance activity, not engagement). No human reviewer engagement or approval. Small scope (2 files) insufficient to overcome systematic non-acceptance history.

Author has 0% merge rate (0/1 prior). Maintainer comment 'Fixed via latest version' is vague and does not constitute approval or merge confirmation. No explicit merge language, no commit hash, no detailed procedure. Author is first-time contributor with zero prior merge history. Lack of clarity on maintainer's intent combined with zero merge history = non-merge signal (P-6-2 pattern: first-time contributor, zero prior merges, maintainer comment present but not explicit approval).

Maintainer comment 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' is conditional language indicating the PR was closed pending author response. No explicit approval or merge confirmation. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with zero merge history. Single file change is focused, but maintainer's phrasing suggests the issue is not yet resolved. Terminal closure signal from maintainer.

Contributor comment explicitly states 'This change has been landed as part of the bulk Feishu integration PR: #14448. Closing this PR as superseded to keep the queue clean.' This is a terminal supersession signal (P-7-2 pattern). Work was absorbed by another PR (#14448). Author has 0% merge rate (0/2 prior), but supersession comment overrides all other factors. PR will not be merged independently.

Author comment 'Closing per request' indicates PR was closed at maintainer/community request. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with 0% merge rate. Author provided technical follow-up on Greptile feedback but ultimately closed rather than merged. Terminal closure signal from author statement.

Author sebslight has strong merge history: 16/17 prior PRs merged (94.1% rate). Has maintainer label—90.7% merge rate indicator. Medium-sized feature PR (32 files) across multiple categories (docs, gateway, cli, commands, agents). CI green per Greptile review. Focused scope on path resolution. High prior merge rate overrides file count concern. Maintainer label + experienced author = reliable merge signal.

Author 0xRaini has 8/52 prior PRs merged (15.4% merge rate)—significantly below 24% baseline. Author is experienced contributor but has low acceptance rate. Small XS fix (1 file) on cron logic. CI green, author pinged maintainer for review. However: low author merge rate, no maintainer label, no approval yet, and code-review bot hit usage limits (negative signal of triage constraints). Despite focused scope and technical quality, author's persistent low acceptance rate suggests closure.

Contributor comment states 'I applied the documentation fix directly to main and kept scope docs-only.' This indicates the fix was applied directly to main branch outside this PR. The fix has landed elsewhere (P-6-1 pattern: 'Fixed on main'). Author has 0% merge rate (0/1 prior). Work was absorbed by maintainer directly, PR will not be merged independently. Terminal signal: fix already landed.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed PR citing >20 labels as 'too noisy'. Pattern P-13 applies: PRs with 20+ labels trigger automated closure. Additionally, author Ayush10 has 0% merge rate across 4 prior PRs (0/4 merged) with no human reviewer engagement, XL-sized scope (1536 files changed), and failed rebase. Multiple compounding non-merge signals.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed PR citing >20 labels as 'too noisy'. Pattern P-13 applies: PRs with 20+ labels trigger automated closure. Additionally, author Ayush10 has 0% merge rate across 5 prior PRs (0/5 merged), XL-sized scope (1536 files), failed rebase, and no human reviewer approval.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed PR citing >20 labels as 'too noisy'. Pattern P-13 applies: PRs with 20+ labels trigger automated closure. Additionally, author Ayush10 has 0% merge rate across 6 prior PRs (0/6 merged), XL-sized scope (1537 files), failed rebase, and no human reviewer approval.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed PR citing >20 labels as 'too noisy'. Pattern P-13 applies: PRs with 20+ labels trigger automated closure. Additionally, author Ayush10 has 0% merge rate across 8 prior PRs (0/8 merged), XL-sized scope (1537 files), failed rebase, and no human reviewer engagement.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed PR citing >20 labels as 'too noisy'. Pattern P-13 applies: PRs with 20+ labels trigger automated closure. Additionally, author Ayush10 has 0% merge rate across 11 prior PRs (0/11 merged), XL-sized scope (1536 files), failed rebase, and no human reviewer approval despite automated Codex review.

Terminal non-merge signal: Automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly closed PR citing >20 labels as 'too noisy'. Pattern P-13 applies: PRs with 20+ labels trigger automated closure. Additionally, author Ayush10 has 0% merge rate across 12 prior PRs (0/12 merged), XL-sized scope (1536 files), failed rebase, and no human reviewer engagement.

Terminal non-merge signal: Contributor Glucksberg explicitly notes PR #6735 appears to implement the same fix and suggests consolidation. Pattern P-15 (supersession): 'Duplicate triage note' comment indicates superseded status. Additionally, author shayan919293 is first-time contributor (1 prior PR, 0 merged, 0% merge rate) with no maintainer approval. Member sebslight's comment appears to be automated closure. The supersession reference combined with first-time contributor status and lack of maintainer engagement makes merge unlikely.

Strong positive signals: Author abdelsfane has 100% merge rate (4/4 merged) indicating high-quality contributor. PR has maintainer-level engagement from HenryLoenwind (CONTRIBUTOR with deep involvement), active iterative review cycle with Greptile-apps (5 review rounds), and focused scope (13 files, M-sized). Greptile and HenryLoenwind engaged in substantive discussion of edge cases and fixes. However, no explicit approval comment or maintainer label visible, and ongoing technical debate about edge cases (sensitive field redaction, schema regression concerns). The 100% prior merge rate and active maintainer engagement are strong positive signals, but lack of explicit approval and unresolved technical questions create moderate uncertainty.

CI failure blocks merge: rmdmattingly (NONE) reports strict file-size guard failure in code-analysis. `src/cli/update-cli.ts` exceeds size limit (1355→1360 lines, +5 in strict mode). Suggested fix requires refactoring into helper function. While author 0xRaini has reasonable history (71 prior PRs, 12 merged, 16.9% merge rate) and issue is acknowledged with a `.` response indicating awareness, the PR cannot merge without addressing the file-size guard. The maintainer suggestion to move logic to a helper indicates rework required. Unless a follow-up commit addresses this, the PR will not merge.

Positive signals: Author AI-Reviewer-QS has strong history (3 prior PRs, 2 merged, 66.7% merge rate). PR has focused scope (4 files, S-sized label), relevant categories (gateway, commands), and has received automated Greptile review (1 review comment). However, missing explicit approval comment, maintainer label, or maintainer engagement. No human reviewer approval visible despite automated review. The prior merge rate and focused scope are positive, but lack of explicit approval and maintainer engagement introduce moderate uncertainty. Size-S label historically stronger than other categories, supporting moderate confidence.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with XS scope but zero human reviewer engagement. Member comment 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' signals closure. Pattern P-8 (zero reviews/comments from first-time contributor) applies. Greptile-only review is automated, not human. Lack of maintainer label or approval despite member presence indicates low merge probability.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with small scope (2 files) but zero human reviewer engagement. Author comment signals willingness to extend work ('work on the next seven in a batch'), but no maintainer approval or label present. Greptile provided automated review (4 comments), but no human reviewer has engaged. Pattern P-8 (zero reviews/comments from first-time contributor) applies. Lack of approval or maintainer comment indicates closure.

Author comment contains explicit merge metadata: 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with gate confirmation (pnpm lint && pnpm build && pnpm test). Pattern P-2-2 applies: commit-hash-backed or detailed-procedure-backed merge statements are terminal positive signals overriding author history (0.0% merge rate, first-time contributor), review absence, and label absence. The merge receipt explicitly states the landing procedure and validation gate, constituting a confirmed merge signal despite XS/S scope (12 files, ~M size) and first-time contributor status.

XL-sized PR (43 files, explicitly labeled 'size: XL') from first-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) without maintainer label or human reviewer approval. Pattern P-4 applies: 'Large feature PRs (XL size, 20+ files) from first-time contributors without maintainer labels are unlikely to merge regardless of author engagement or review cycles.' Author enthusiasm comment ('first ever PR for a public project. I'm super excited') and mention of opportunity do not overcome structural barriers. Member comment 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' signals closure. Greptile-only review is insufficient.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with focused scope (2 files, XS) and high community engagement (4 comments from users 'mattmiddlesworth' and 'danitt' confirming fix addresses their connectivity issues). Member comment present. Greptile provided automated review with substantive comments (2 file-level reviews). Pattern P-9 (maintainer comment stating fix landed elsewhere) does NOT apply—member comment does not state 'Fixed in #NNNN' or 'Fixed on main', just signals closure protocol. User testimonials ('100% addressed my connectivity issue') provide strong implicit approval signal despite formal review absence. Small scope and user-validated fix overcome first-time contributor negative history.

Author sebslight is MEMBER with 100% prior merge rate (4/4 prior PRs merged). Has 'maintainer' label (90.7% merge rate signal per dataset). M-sized scope (14 files, docs-heavy). Greptile provided substantive automated review (1 file, 3 comments). Member authorship and maintainer label are extremely strong positive signals. Despite no formal human reviewer approval visible, member status and label history override review absence requirement.

Author's explicit comment: 'Closing to open a fresh PR with the same commit; labels on the prior PR were noisy.' This is a terminal self-closure signal indicating the PR was abandoned in favor of a reopen. Prior greptile comment noted 'Too many files changed for review (409 files found, 100 file limit)', indicating scope bloat from fork merge (Pattern P-12 adjacent: excessive file count triggers closure). Author's rebasing effort and reopen intent signal this PR will not merge independently. Pattern P-8-2 (stalled PR with author maintenance activity but no maintainer engagement) also applies—author force-pushed to rebase but is closing proactively.

Author's explicit comment: 'Closing per founder request (pause). No merge.' This is a terminal closure signal stating the PR will not be merged per founder directive. Overrides all other signals including large scope (70 files, XL), multi-category labels (docs, gateway, extensions, cli, agents), and technical substance. Author self-closed with explicit 'No merge' statement constitutes definitive non-merge outcome.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with M/L scope (24 files) addressing 5 documented open issues (#10616, #10614, #10613, #10610, #10607). Contributor comment from Takhoffman signals merge approval: 'This will go out in the next OpenClaw release' with reference to subsequent PR #12988. This explicit merge-into-release language constitutes Pattern P-2-2 (merge receipt confirmation), though not a commit hash. High-engagement comment (2 comments from author + contributor approval). Addresses multiple user-reported issues (multi-issue fix). Greptile review present. Scope breadth (24 files) and first-time status present risk, but explicit release-cycle confirmation from contributor overrides.

Experienced contributor (34 prior PRs, 35.3% merge rate) with XS scope (3 files) and both 'trusted-contributor' and 'experienced-contributor' labels. Windows CI failure identified as environmental (Vitest worker crash, not test failure) by rmdmattingly with diagnosis ('460 test files passed; 3128 tests passed; then 1 unhandled error'). Pattern P-19 (first-time contributors with XS + failing CI) does NOT apply—lailoo is experienced contributor. CI failure is platform-specific and transient (Vitest worker issue), not code-related per triage. Both label presence and author experience overcome CI signal noise. Small scope focused on web-ui markdown image rendering.
Author explicitly closes the PR stating it has become out-of-sync with main and iOS was already updated. Terminal self-closure signal from contributor overrides all other factors.

Maintainer comment (mbelinky) states 'Broader architecture parts from this PR have been superseded by newer alpha-core' and indicates selective bring-over into different branch. Terminal supersession signal per P-14 (superseded by another initiative). PR will not merge independently despite having tests and 21 files.

Contributor comment (clawdinator) closes the PR in favor of another PR. Terminal supersession signal per P-14 despite only 2 files and focused scope. Low-merge-rate author (0% on 1 prior PR) adds no countervailing signal.

First-time contributor with focused scope (XS, 2 files, media transcription fix). Has tests, active positive engagement (5 comments with Greptile review + copilot review + author responsiveness to feedback demonstrating bug fixes). Greptile identified edge case, author fixed it (commit dcd8aa52f), Greptile re-reviewed and affirmed fix. Despite no human reviewer approval and no maintainer label, the technical quality signal is strong and engagement is high. Medium confidence due to lack of explicit human approval and maintainer engagement.

Author with 0% merge rate (14 prior PRs, 0 merged) despite active engagement with Greptile reviews. Pattern of repeated maintenance comments (rebasing, re-reviews, bug fixes) without maintainer approval or engagement signals stalled PR (P-9). No maintainer label, no human reviewer engagement beyond automated Greptile. Focused scope (1 file) does not overcome compounded signals of persistent non-acceptance and maintenance stalling.

Author explicitly closes the PR stating the branch is >1600 commits behind main. Terminal self-closure signal overrides all other factors. Additionally, Greptile identified that the hook is never executed (no call sites wiring it into the pipeline), which is a structural defect. Author with 0% merge rate (18 prior PRs) and small-sized feature further support non-merge.

Author (0xRaini, 19.2% merge rate) explicitly closes the PR with reasoned explanation: 'the fix is too aggressive' and identifies architectural conflict (replyToMode=off breaking thread routing). Terminal self-closure with technical justification. Author acknowledges the fix requires more nuanced approach. Despite focused scope (XS, 4 files) and decent prior merge rate, explicit self-closure overrides (P-1 alternative: author recognizes implementation flaw).

Maintainer (thewilloftheshadow) comment states: 'Banning user due to spam/slop + copying other users PRs and pinging users'. Terminal moderation action signal. PR is from 0xRaini (who previously had decent merge rate of 18.3%) but maintainer ban overrides all technical quality signals. Greptile review + human approval (sjd9021) cannot override moderation action.

Author mbelinky with maintainer label (90.7% merge rate for PRs with this label per guidelines). Small-medium scope (10 files, S size). Has tests and security focus. Single Greptile review with minimal blocking feedback. Maintainer label is strong positive signal despite lack of explicit human approval comments. Security/Browser feature with good documentation support (docs/ changes included). Author has decent prior merge rate (22.2%, 2/9). Label presence overrides typical approval absence for focused, documented PRs.

Author (Clawborn) comment states 'Recreated from clean branch as #19105'. Terminal supersession signal per P-14 — the work has been absorbed into a new PR (#19105). Original will not merge. Author has trusted-contributor label and 23.1% prior merge rate, but explicit supersession comment overrides these positive signals.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with focused scope (4 files, agents category). Has automated review from greptile-apps with 3 comments flagging architectural concern (ProxyAgent creation per request). Member comment 'sebslight' appears truncated but suggests closure ('If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen'). No human reviewer approval despite greptile feedback. Architectural concern without resolution guidance = low merge signal. Matches P-8: zero human reviewer engagement despite automated review.

Author with 0% merge rate (2 prior PRs, 0 merged). No labels, no comments, no reviews. Single-file fix (minimal scope) but zero engagement. Matches P-8: first-time-equivalent contributor (0% history) with zero reviews and zero comments. No maintainer label or approval. Low merge probability despite narrow scope.

Author with 0% merge rate (2 prior PRs) but PR has gateway label (578 PRs in top categories). Has tests (2 files: .test.ts + .ts). Member comment from sebslight present (truncated but suggests potential closure workflow). Greptile automated review with 2 comments + 3 reviews total. Author self-reviewed with 2 comments (self-advocacy). Narrow scope (2 files). Matches P-3 constraint (0% merge rate across 2+ PRs) but has some positive signals: focused scope, tests present, greptile engagement, category signal. Risk: no explicit human approval visible, member comment incomplete.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs). Greptile review flags critical issue: PR deletes pnpm-lock.yaml entirely, breaking deterministic installs/CI (explicit mention in comments). Member gumadeiras suggests redirecting to SKILL/ClawHub rather than merging. No approval signals. Lockfile deletion is a blocking architectural issue. Matches P-6: new feature (marketing/OpenRouter) from first-time contributor lacks tests (actually has anti-signal: breaks build), no maintainer approval, and maintainer comment suggests alternative path (SKILL).

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs). Contributor HenryLoenwind states 'There's already a better one for this: #9531'. Contributor vignesh07 explicitly states: 'I took cue from this and landed a focused follow-up on main' with 'Appreciate the contribution' but indicates the fix was already landed elsewhere with expanded scope. Matches P-11: maintainer/contributor comment states fix is 'Fixed on main' / 'Landed' elsewhere. This PR will not merge independently despite focused scope and greptile review.

First-time contributor (1 prior PR, 0 merged = 0% rate). Contributor Takhoffman explicitly comments 'Appears to be a duplicate'. Matches P-14: contributor comment stating PR is superseded/duplicate is terminal non-merge signal regardless of technical quality. Same files as #11302 (qmd-manager.ts). Related to #9531 mentioned in #11302 comments.

Author blazerui now has 2 prior PRs (0 merged = 0% rate). No comments, no approvals. Greptile review only (automated). Same files as #11302 and #11330 (qmd-manager.ts, .gitignore). Part of duplicate cluster around QMD memory search fixes. Author is attempting multiple variations on same issue. Matches P-8: zero human reviewer engagement despite greptile review. Zero comments despite repetition across 3 PRs suggests low engagement quality.

Author arosstale has 65 prior PRs with 0% merge rate (extremely strong negative signal per P-3). Has trusted-contributor label and XS size (positive signals), but only automated review (Copilot error). Matches P-20: first-time contributors with maintainer/trusted-contributor label but zero human reviewer comments/approvals do not reliably merge. Additionally, author's 0% merge rate across 65 PRs is compounded non-merge signal (P-12). Copilot error means no human review of substance. Trusted label alone insufficient without human approval.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs). 0xRaini (non-member) flags edge case with custom providers but doesn't approve. Contributor HenryLoenwind explicitly states: 'we have a perfectly good PR that actually finishes implementing the bad PR that caused that. There's no need to twiddle with the symptoms when the whole feature that caused it is broken'. This is functionally a supersession/rejection comment: maintainer/contributor indicating the approach is wrong and a better PR exists. Matches P-11 variant: maintainer indicates issue is addressed elsewhere and this PR approach is wrong. No approval, no maintainer label.

Author has 1 prior PR (0% merge rate). PR was merged accidentally. Member sebslight explicitly states: 'Reverted in d0697d5aa (reverts merge commit). This PR was merged accidentally, so we reverted it to restore the prior Windows session store behavior.' Matches P-11: maintainer comment stating change was reverted/undone is terminal non-merge signal. The PR is already formally reverted on main. This is a closed/reverted PR that should not be re-merged. Despite architectural merit (atomic writes) and author responsiveness to greptile feedback, the maintainer reverted it as introducing regression.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XS-sized PR (1 file). Member comment from sebslight reads as dismissive ('.') with closure implication ('If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen'). No human reviewer approval despite greptile review. Pattern P-8-2 (zero reviews/comments from first-time contributors have low merge probability) applies, though there is 1 comment. The terse member response suggests low priority or incorrect fix. Zero positive engagement signals.

Terminal non-merge signal: Pattern P-12-2 applies — automated triage bot (openclaw-barnacle) explicitly states PR is being closed because it has more than 20 labels (high label count indicates 'too noisy' branch). duplicates.evidence: Both PRs address identical feature: allowing $schema key in config for JSON Schema editor support. Created 5 minutes apart (15004 @ 2026-02-12T21:30:22Z, 15009 @ 2026-02-12T21:34:31Z). Both XS-sized, both config category. Different authors (arosstale vs shtse8) but duplicate scope. PR #15004 closed by member with architectural explanation (need published schema endpoint); PR #15009 auto-closed due to author spam enforcement. Both now closed, but represent simultaneous duplicate submissions addressing same feature gap.

PR #11867 author explicitly states 'Superseded by new PR with clean rebase onto latest upstream/main. See replacement PR' with reference to #15825. This PR is explicitly superseded by PR #15825 (not in this batch). PR #11867 is the original; #15825 is the replacement with clean rebase. Not a duplicate within batch but represents supersession pattern.

Both PRs address Slack file attachment handling. PR #4158 'fix(slack): support multiple file attachments in messages' and PR #10685 'fix(slack): resolve all file attachments instead of only the first' target the same issue: allowing resolution of all Slack file attachments rather than only the first. PR #10685's author comment confirms: 'Upstream commit c76288bdf (PR #15447) already fixes issue #7536 along with #11892. The upstream fix implements the same solution this PR intended: Changed resolveSlackMedia() to return an array of all downloaded files - Updated prepare handler to populate MediaPaths/MediaUrl'. Both touch identical files: src/slack/monitor/media.test.ts, src/slack/monitor/media.ts, src/slack/monitor/message-handler/prepare.ts. PR #10685 is explicitly superseded by #15447. PR #4158 may also be superseded by the same upstream fix, making these duplicates/related PRs addressing the same functional gap.

Both PRs from same author (cortexuvula), created same date (2026-01-31), both Android app fixes, both closed with identical rationale ('moved to our own ClawReach implementation'), both marked stale, both have zero prior merges. Likely related work abandoned in favor of internal implementation.

All six PRs from same author (Ayush10) created within 8 hours (2026-01-30), all have identical automated closure reason (>20 labels, too noisy), all have ~1536-1537 files changed touching identical system files (.github/workflows, .pi/extensions, AGENTS.md, README.md, etc.), all have identical label set (25 labels across channel/app/component categories), all have failed rebases, and all have 0% merge rate author history. This appears to be a single repository state corruption or automated batch submission error rather than 6 independent PRs. Each has distinct fix titles (slack thread_broadcast, history tool_use pairing, hooks slug generator, agents toolCall normalization, Windows command spawning, gateway WebChat errors) but identical file corruption pattern. Likely supersession: all 6 should be closed and replaced with properly scoped PRs.

PR #4997 contains explicit 'Duplicate triage note' comment from Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) stating 'PR #6735 appears to implement the same fix. Consider consolidating or closing one in favor of the other.' Both PRs target the same failing node: 'classify 404/model-not-found errors as failover reason' in agents/failover-error.ts context. PR #4997 has 6 files changed in agents and config; superseded PR reference suggests #6735 is the consolidated version. Terminal supersession signal per Pattern P-15.

Both touch agents subsystem, both first-time contributors with 0.0% merge rate, both XS scope with 1-2 files. However, no explicit supersession language or cross-reference in comments. Different functional areas (compaction retry vs. hook integration). Insufficient evidence for confident duplicate classification.

Both have author comments indicating closure/non-merge intent. PR #9673 author explicitly closes to 'open a fresh PR with the same commit'. PR #9679 author closes 'per founder request'. Both represent author/stakeholder pauses rather than technical duplicates. Different scopes and components. Not true duplicates but temporally adjacent closure signals.

Both PRs address iOS gateway/chat integration with overlapping file changes (ChatSheet.swift, IOSGatewayChatTransport.swift, GatewayConnectionController.swift, NodeAppModel.swift, RootCanvas.swift, SettingsTab.swift, TalkModeManager.swift). PR #2134 is older (2026-01-26) and explicitly closes as out-of-sync; PR #2894 (2026-01-27, 21 files) appears to be the expanded/superseded version. Maintainer comment in #2894 confirms broader parts supersede earlier work.

All three PRs by author blazerui address QMD memory search robustness. All modify same files (src/memory/qmd-manager.ts, .gitignore). PR #11302 has explicit comment linking to #9531 (better existing fix). PR #11330 tagged as duplicate by Takhoffman. PR #11345 appears to be third attempt by same author. vignesh07 comment on #11302 states 'I took cue from this and landed a focused follow-up on main' — indicating the issue was already fixed elsewhere. Author attempting multiple variations on same fix across 3 consecutive PRs within 1 hour (17:35-18:27 UTC).

Both PRs involve compaction/context token accumulation fixes in agents module. PR #13842 (trailing custom entries fix) is superseded by #13841. PR #15218 (contextTokens cap) is superseded by upstream context-window-guard.ts implementation. Both authors self-close citing work landed elsewhere. While not direct duplicates of each other, both represent narrow compaction-related fixes that were consolidated into broader solutions.

Both PRs are automatically closed by openclaw-barnacle bot citing >20 labels as 'too noisy'. Both involve massive file changes (1537 and 4629 files respectively) indicating branch contamination. Both have rebase/review failure comments. Both suggest accidental inclusion of entire main branch or repository structure rather than targeted fixes.

Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly flags PR #2887 as duplicate of PR #5503 in triage comment: 'PR #5503 appears to implement the same fix. Consider consolidating efforts or closing one in favor of the other.' Terminal duplicate signal with recommendation to consolidate or close.

Both PRs have identical triage closure pattern: >20 labels (24 each), massive file counts (1536 vs 780), both closed by openclaw-barnacle with identical closure message about 'more than 20 labels usually means branch too noisy'. Both have 0% merge rate authors. Both are automated rejections, not technical duplicates, but represent same problem pattern (branch contamination from fork main/uncontrolled scope expansion).

Both PRs are explicitly superseded by author comments: #10396 author states 'Superseded by #10406' (clean replacement); #17619 author states 'PR superseded #17617'. Both have 0% merge rate authors. Both will not merge due to explicit supersession. However, they target different areas (docker-setup vs agent bootstrap), so not true duplicates—rather, both represent instances of deliberate author replacement patterns.
